author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Netanyahu Tells Trump Israel Must ‘Complete Its Victory’
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he told President-elect Donald J. Trump that the country had delivered “a tough blow” against Hamas and Hezbollah.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he had told President-elect Donald J. Trump in a telephone conversation over the weekend that Israel needed to “complete its victory” over Iranian proxies and bring back hostages held in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: This Is the Secret to the Perfect Baked Potato
description: A simple trick yields crisp outsides and fluffy insides, ready to be topped in three smart, exciting ways from Eric Kim.
content: Turns out, the baked potato has always been big and great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson
title: An ‘Architectural Dream World’ Filled With Hundreds of Dollhouses
description: The artist Dennis Maher — who rescued his Buffalo, N.Y., home from the brink of destruction — has always treasured what others have overlooked.
content: When the visual artist Dennis Maher, 48, acquired his 1890s duplex in Buffalo, N.Y., in 2009, it was slated for demolition. The relatively unassuming wooden building in the city’s historic Fargo Estate neighborhood, with a gable roof and two stacked front porches, had sat unoccupied for a year and was scheduled to be replaced by a parking lot. Maher stepped in, and for $10,000, the house was his.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.1 Million Homes in California
description: A craftsman-style house in Oakland, a 1922 home in Stockton and a midcentury modern-style house in Santa Rosa
content: This two-bedroom, two-bathroom, wood-shingled house is a few blocks from College and Telegraph Avenues and their bakeries, coffee shops and restaurants. A Safeway and a Trader Joe’s are each 15-minutes on foot, as is Market Hall and its many food stalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Short Books Are Perfect for Our Distracted Age
description: There is something special about works I can read in full on a rainy Sunday afternoon or in the lamplight hours between supper and bedtime.
content: When the news is one report of human suffering — or environmental degradation, or violation of democratic norms — after another, people might be forgiven for averting their eyes from the headlines in favor of getting a better night’s sleep. The only problem: In a democracy, tuning out means giving the foxes full run of the henhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: We Were All Just Catching Up to Lorraine O’Grady
description: Through her writing and performances, the artist helped new audiences to understand the cultural roots of racism and sexism.
content: Lorraine O’Grady, the conceptual and performance artist who died on Dec. 13 at age 90, was an inveterate correspondent — you never got a short note from Lorraine, you got the full intensity of her warmth, intellect and inquisitiveness in long missives often sent in the middle of the night, her favored time to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump Holds Forth on Vaccines, the Media and Drones
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced a $100 billion investment from SoftBank, a Japanese company, then jumped from one topic to another in his first news conference since the election.
content: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Donald Trump and the presidential transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Held His First News Conference as President-Elect
description: Also, Syria’s new leader called for sanctions to be lifted. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Donald Trump invited reporters to his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida today for his first news conference since the election. The president-elect spent nearly half an hour jumping from one topic to another, including border security, tax cuts and the war in Ukraine, before taking questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps and Mark Abramson
title: Seeking Relief From Brain Injury, Some Veterans Turn to Psychedelics
description: Unable to find effective treatments at home, veterans with brain-injury symptoms are going abroad for psychedelics like ibogaine that are illegal in the U.S.
content: A van full of U.S. Special Operations veterans crossed the border into Mexico on a sunny day in July to execute a mission that, even to them, sounded pretty far out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Why Do You Think the Killing of a Health Care C.E.O. Has Sparked Such an Intense National Conversation?
description: Have you been following the story? What do you think the news and our reactions to it say about America today?
content: Please keep in mind that this forum is for teenagers only. While there are many places on NYTimes.com for adults to comment, this is the only dedicated spot for the voices of young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles, Hank Shteamer and Lindsay Zoladz
title: 11 New Entries to a Hallowed Catalog: The Holiday Album
description: Our critics on Christmas records from Jacob Collier, Megan Moroney, the Christmas Tree-O and more.
content: A holiday album offers musicians a chance to adopt — or reinvent — a classic format and show fans a different side of themselves. Here’s a sampling of this year’s releases, from singers exploring the standards and artists rethinking the meaning of the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jay-Z Will Seek Dismissal of Assault Lawsuit His Lawyer Calls a ‘Sham’
description: The woman who accused him of raping her in 2000, when she was a minor, acknowledged to NBC that there were inconsistencies in her account, but stood by her claim.
content: Lawyers for Jay-Z plan to ask a judge to toss a lawsuit accusing the rapper of raping a 13-year-old in 2000, pointing to what they described as “glaring inconsistencies” that emerged in an NBC interview of the accuser, who was not named in the suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder
title: Sudden Loss of Undocumented Workers Threw Tech Supplier Into Upheaval
description: Jabil says it required “herculean efforts” to replace employees from a staffing agency. Other businesses are bracing for “an enforcement storm” under President-elect Trump.
content: Jabil, a major manufacturer of electronics components for the tech industry, made a startling discovery in the spring of 2021: It had been relying on dozens of undocumented workers, contracted from a staffing agency, to power its manufacturing sites near Silicon Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Reverberations of the Daniel Penny Verdict
description: Penny was acquitted in the chokehold killing of Jordan Neely. The case has set off a debate over justice, race and the treatment of mentally ill people.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll take a closer look at the verdict that cleared Daniel Penny in the chokehold death of Jordan Neely, a fellow passenger on an F train who witnesses said had been shouting at riders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Zakir Hussain, Tabla Virtuoso Who Fused Musical Traditions, Dies at 73
description: His collaborators included John McLaughlin, Béla Fleck, Ravi Shankar, Herbie Hancock, Yo-Yo Ma and members of the Grateful Dead.
content: Zakir Hussain, a percussionist and composer who was both a master of North Indian classical music and a linchpin of far-reaching world-music fusions, died on Sunday in San Francisco. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: A Mild Defense of Lara Trump
description: The Senate takes itself seriously, but its members aren’t always public-servant all-stars.
content: Senator Lara Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Maya C. Miller
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Trump’s Health Secretary Pick, Meets With Lawmakers
description: Mr. Kennedy has begun meeting with Republican senators to build support for his confirmation, which could be imperiled by his anti-vaccine stance.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for health secretary, began meeting with Republican lawmakers late Monday afternoon to make his case for a spot in Mr. Trump’s cabinet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Sohn and Kristina Samulewski
title: Why I’m Not Dreading Holiday Chores This Season
description: Holidays often mean more work. Here’s how to view that work differently.
content: After having kids, the United Methodist minister Lydia Sohn was an avid subscriber to services that promised to make her life easier: She DoorDashed dinner, fixed furniture with the help of TaskRabbit and hired a cleaner. But that all changed when she discovered the philosophy behind the Benedictine monks who embraced physical labor in their daily lives. In this episode, Sohn argues something magical happens when you begin viewing household chores as more than just another item on your to-do list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: Dick Van Arsdale, 81, One of First Identical Twins in the N.B.A., Dies
description: A three-time All-Star, he played for the Knicks and the Phoenix Suns. For one season, he and Tom Van Arsdale were hard-to-tell-apart teammates.
content: Dick Van Arsdale, a three-time All-Star who, with his brother, Tom, was half of the first set of identical twins to play in the N.B.A. after starring and confusing opponents and teammates alike in high school and at Indiana University, died on Monday at his home in Phoenix. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
title: German Government Collapses at a Perilous Time for Europe
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote, deepening the political turbulence in one of the continent’s most powerful economies.
content: The German government collapsed on Monday as Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote in Parliament, deepening a crisis of leadership across Europe at a time of mounting economic and security challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Chaotic Start
description: We cover the people who will surround Donald Trump in his second term.
content: Donald Trump has named most of the advisers and cabinet officials whom he wants to surround him in a second term. To make sense of the team, I asked for help from three of my colleagues who cover Trump: Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Jonathan Swan. Our exchange follows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Percival Everett’s Prose Is Having a Moment. How Is His Poetry?
description: The winner of this year’s National Book Award in fiction has published several collections of poems. Our critic takes a look.
content: Percival Everett’s first novel was published in 1983. How long ago was that? It was same year Madonna, R.E.M. and Metallica released their first albums. Much of the world has only recently begun to catch up with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, the Islamist rebel movement that just spearheaded the overthrow of the Assad dynasty in Syria, has roots in the Islamic State and Al Qaeda. But since around 2016, the group has modified and moderated its own jihadist orientation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Mother Inferior
description: A sister with history shows up at the emperor’s palace. Not everyone is pleased. Nor should everyone be.
content: It is a time of revelations. In this week’s episode of “Dune: Prophecy,” character after character learns some shattering truth about another — or the audience is clued in to something previously unknown about a familiar face. It’s about time, too. In a show this focused on plot and lore, at times to its dramatic detriment, the characters involved in both deserve a real turn in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Hegseth’s Guard Left the Army After the Beating of a Civilian During Training
description: John Hasenbein, who has escorted Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary to meetings on Capitol Hill, said he was unjustly prosecuted for the 2019 episode.
content: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Donald Trump and the presidential transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Private Schools Group Apologizes After Claims of Antisemitism at Event
description: After criticism from Jewish groups over speeches at a conference, the president of the National Association of Independent Schools said future addresses would be vetted.
content: A prominent national private schools group has apologized for remarks some speakers made at a conference about diversity and inclusion earlier this month, after leaders of several Jewish organizations condemned the comments as antisemitic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ways to Fix the Health Insurance Debacle
description: Responses to an essay by Andrew Witty, the C.E.O. of UnitedHealth Group. Also: Threats to democracy, in Hungary and America; a check on Trump; avoiding taxes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Stays Silent on Syria, With Russia’s Future There in Question
description: In an hourlong televised meeting with his top military brass, Vladimir Putin left Syria unmentioned and made it clear that winning in Ukraine was his top priority.
content: For an hour on Monday, President Vladimir V. Putin and his defense minister presided over a televised, annual meeting of the Russian military’s top brass. They held forth on NATO, Ukraine and issues as obscure as mortgages for service members.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Blunt U.S. Ambassador in Nicety-Bound Japan
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 16, 2024.
content: “If you only want to do big things that nobody disagrees with, they’re not going to be very big.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Neil MacFarquhar, Natasha Singer, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Trump Threatens More News Outlets, and Injuries at Amazon’s Warehouses
description: Plus, a troubling trend in American schools.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Sweet and Sour, Festive and Fast
description: This cranberry-orange chicken works just as well for a quiet Tuesday dinner as it does a Friday night gathering with friends.
content: As a festive main dish, chicken thighs may sound like a stretch. As opposed to, say, a glistening, bronze-skinned whole roasted bird, a panful of thighs can feel a little basic — not so much “Happy holidays!” as “Welp, it’s Tuesday.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Karoun Demirjian, Jonathan Swan, Rob Szypko, Luke Vander Ploeg, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Nina Feldman, Rachel Quester, Devon Taylor, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Pete Hegseth Was Toast. The MAGA Swarm Came to His Rescue.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his supporters exerted intense political pressure to salvage his pick for the Department of Defense.
content: Warning: this episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How Does A.I. Think? Here’s One Theory.
description: It may employ a kind of reasoning humans use all the time — but you’ve probably never heard of it.
content: In the roughly two years since the public release of ChatGPT, artificial intelligence has advanced far more rapidly than humanity has learned to use its good features and to suppress its bad ones. On the bad side, for example, it turns out that A.I. is really good at manipulating and deceiving its human “masters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Arlo Brown
title: An Exiled Conductor’s Once and Future Orchestras Present Dueling Concerts
description: Banished from his ensembles after striking a singer, John Eliot Gardiner has assembled a new group, with the same programming at the same venue.
content: Marten Root, a flutist specializing in historical instruments, has played under the conductor John Eliot Gardiner for over 35 years, and considers him a profoundly intelligent and honest musician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous and Patrick Kingsley
title: Tice’s Mother Asks Netanyahu for Pause in Syria Strikes to Search for Journalist
description: Debra Tice wrote to the Israeli prime minister that her family had “credible information” that Austin Tice may be held in a prison outside Damascus, in an area where Israel had been conducting military operations.
content: The mother of the missing American journalist Austin Tice has told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in a letter that her family has “credible information” that Mr. Tice may be held in a prison outside the Syrian capital, Damascus, and urged the Israelis to pause military strikes in the area to allow rescuers to search the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: E.B. Furgurson III, Who Covered Massacre at His Newspaper, Dies at 70
description: After five people were killed in the newsroom, he set up a work space in the back of his pickup truck and made sure the next day’s issue was published.
content: E.B. Furgurson III, a reporter who, after five of his colleagues at the Maryland newspaper The Capital were massacred in their newsroom by a grudge-fueled gunman, helped produce the next day’s issue from his pickup truck, died on Nov. 25 in Annapolis, Md. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Real Estate Leaders Sue to Stop New York City’s Overhaul of Broker Fees
description: A law in New York City shifting broker fees from renters to landlords is set to take effect in June. Real estate leaders want to stop it.
content: Real estate leaders in New York City filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to halt a new law that would shift expensive broker fees from renters to landlords.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
title: Ex-Bangladeshi Leader Orchestrated Mass Disappearances, Inquiry Finds
description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and top officials are implicated in a centralized program that abducted dissidents and held them in secret prisons, an official commission’s preliminary report said.
content: Bangladesh’s ousted prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, and senior officials orchestrated a centralized program of enforced disappearances with thousands of likely victims, a commission set up by the country’s interim government said in a preliminary report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Powell’s Fed Appears Headed for Another Collision With Trump
description: Rates may not come down as much or as quickly as had been expected, just as Trump — a self-declared “low-rate guy” — returns to the White House.
content: Inside the halls of the Federal Reserve’s headquarters overlooking Constitution Avenue in Washington, casual mentions of the incoming Trump administration are cautious and infrequent. That’s by design.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicola Guess
title: Why Ultraprocessed Foods Aren’t Always Bad
description: The category of ultraprocessed foods is so broad it borders on useless.
content: The way we eat desperately needs to change. Experts estimate diet is a bigger contributor globally to early death than smoking. In America, nearly half the adult population has Type 2 diabetes or pre-diabetes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: vocational
description: This word has appeared in 220 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word vocational has appeared in 220 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 21 in “How High School Graduates Can Improve Their Earnings Potential” by Steve Lohr:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Carlos Watson, Ozy Media Co-Founder, Is Sentenced to Almost 10 Years in Prison
description: A federal jury in July found Mr. Watson, who started the digital media company in 2013, guilty of trying to defraud investors and lenders.
content: Carlos Watson, a co-founder of the now-defunct digital media company Ozy Media, was sentenced on Monday to almost 10 years in prison for trying to defraud investors and lenders by lying about the company’s finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Syria’s New Leadership Takes Early Steps Toward Recognition
description: A little over a week after taking power, the rebel alliance that led the overthrow of the Assad regime has begun to receive diplomats in the Syrian capital, Damascus.
content: A little more than a week after overthrowing the longtime Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad, the rebel alliance that took power in Syria was making rapid progress toward international recognition of its legitimacy as its officials began to receive diplomats from the United Nations, the Middle East and Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: How the Swedish Dungeons & Dragons Inspired Helldivers 2
description: The studio behind the fastest-selling PlayStation title of all time adjusts its story arc based on corporate decisions by players.
content: As Arrowhead Studios was putting the finishing touches on its multiplayer sci-fi shooter Helldivers 2, Johan Pilestedt was firming up the game’s online infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: 12 Die at Georgian Ski Resort From Suspected Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
description: The police say the bodies were found in a room above an Indian restaurant not long after a generator had been plugged in nearby.
content: Twelve people were found dead of suspected carbon monoxide poisoning in Gudauri, a ski area in the Caucasus Mountains in Georgia, the country’s Ministry of Internal Affairs said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 555
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Tales of Messy Romances, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: Watch how “The Ultimatum,” “Laid” and “Virgin River” test relationships in different ways. Get into the holiday spirit with Josh Groban.
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, Dec. 16 to Dec. 22. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: The Modern Prince Lighting Up the Ballet Stage in Paris
description: Guillaume Diop has reached the highest level in the Paris Opera Ballet. He has also become a fashion-world darling and a symbol of a more diverse France.
content: Guillaume Diop had heard the whispers: His feet were flat, his bottom too big; he would never get into the Paris Opera Ballet School. He proved the naysayers wrong, entering the school at 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cornelia Dean
title: Orrin H. Pilkey, Warrior in a Fight to Save Imperiled Beaches, Dies at 90
description: An eminent geologist, he argued against putting condos and hotels on vulnerable coastal landscapes. Environmentalists applauded; many others didn’t.
content: Orrin H. Pilkey, a coastal geologist whose blunt and often successful arguments against sea walls and other armor on the saltwater beaches of the United States won him reverence from environmentalists and condemnation from developers and politicians, died on Friday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Black Student Enrollment at Harvard Law Drops by More Than Half
description: After a Supreme Court decision ended race-based admissions, some law schools saw a decline in Black and Hispanic students entering this fall. Harvard appeared to have the steepest drop.
content: The number of Black students entering Harvard Law School dropped sharply this fall after last year’s Supreme Court decision banning affirmative action in college admissions, according to enrollment data released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Attia
title: 11 Fun Party Appetizers That Start With Frozen Puff Pastry
description: These golden, flaky bites are sure to impress your guests during the holiday season.
content: The wise Ina Garten once said — then repeated again, and again — “store-bought is fine.” And, each time, she was absolutely right, especially when it comes to puff pastry, the ultimate way to take any party app to the next level. It’s easy to work with, affordable and available at most supermarkets. Put a few sheets to use with these 11 golden, flaky snacks and treats that are sure to impress your guests this holiday season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen
title: Top Canada Minister Resigns, Threatening Trudeau’s Hold on Power
description: Chrystia Freeland, the deputy prime minister and finance minister, had been helping lead Canada’s response to the incoming Trump administration.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s hold on power was threatened on Monday after the deputy prime minister who led Canada’s response to the first Trump administration resigned abruptly, in a stinging rebuke to the country’s leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Blocked Muslim Judicial Nominee Decries Senate ‘Smear Campaign’
description: Adeel Mangi, who would have been the first Muslim American federal appellate court judge, wrote an angry letter to President Biden describing bigotry he faced in the confirmation process.
content: The first Muslim American to be nominated for a federal appellate court judgeship lashed out at senators and the judicial confirmation process in a letter to President Biden on Monday, saying he had been the victim of a bigoted smear campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: How to Understand the Collapse of Germany’s Government, and What’s Next
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote in the German Parliament, ending the unpopular three-party coalition government he has led since 2021.
content: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called a confidence vote in the German Parliament on Monday. He lost by a tally of 394-207, with 116 abstaining. That effectively ends the unpopular government he has led since 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Judge Denies Trump’s Bid to Throw Out Conviction Over Immunity Ruling
description: Justice Juan M. Merchan thwarted one of several attempts by Donald J. Trump to clear his record of 34 felonies before returning to the White House.
content: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Donald Trump and the presidential transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Why America’s Kurdish Allies Are Under Threat in a New Syria
description: The Kurds helped the United States contain the Islamic State. Now they fear a resurgent Turkey that has long considered them an adversary. Here’s a guide.
content: The 13-year civil war between Syria’s government and rebel fighters has ended. But the peril is not over for Syria’s Kurdish minority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden Prepares to Target Chinese Legacy Chips With Trade Investigation
description: The investigation could result in tariffs on older types of chips from China, though the decision would ultimately fall to Trump.
content: The Biden administration is preparing a trade investigation into China’s production of older-model semiconductors, in response to fears that the United States’ growing dependence on these products could pose a national security threat, according to people familiar with the matter and government and industry documents reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Narrator
description: Banias is an 8-year-old living in Gaza, and she has a story to tell — many stories, in fact.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Is Protein Powder a Scam?
description: Most people don’t need to consume this supplement, experts say, but it can be useful in certain situations.
content: On TikTok, influencers tout protein powder as key to building muscle and nourishing their bodies — all in a quick, convenient scoop added to coffee or a smoothie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Israel Carries Out Heavy Strikes on Syria’s Coast, Monitor Says
description: Overnight strikes targeted former army positions, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a war monitor. Israel has said it aims to keep military equipment away from extremists.
content: Israel carried out a heavy wave of airstrikes overnight on Syria’s coastal region, a war monitor said early on Monday, as the Israeli military continued to pound Syria in a bid to destroy the country’s military assets after rebels seized power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas and Tom Johnson
title: Men in Tights and Tutus: The Trocks Turn 50, Humor Intact
description: The Trocks were never interested in making a political statement, their artistic director said. “We are men doing performances of ballet in drag for comedic purposes.”
content: The ballerinas of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo never change. With the never-say-die showbiz spirit of a faded Russian touring company, and a whiff of greasepaint and glamour, Ida Nevasayneva, Maya Thickenthighya and the other ballet warriors are eternally giving heroic performances, triumphantly knocking off a technical trick or two, flirting with the audience, elbowing rivals out of the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Asks Supreme Court to Block Law Banning Its U.S. Operations
description: The company and its Chinese parent invoked the First Amendment in urging the justices to step in before a Jan. 19 deadline to sell or be shut down.
content: TikTok asked the Supreme Court on Monday to temporarily block a law that would effectively ban it in the United States in a matter of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Meets the Press
description: Reflecting on how much has changed, and hasn’t, for Donald Trump since he first became president.
content: Nearly eight years ago, I remember walking into the lobby of Trump Tower to cover President-elect Donald Trump’s first news conference after the 2016 election. On Monday, as I watched him turn Mar-a-Lago into the backdrop of his first news conference since he became president-elect for the second time, I couldn’t help but reflect on how much has changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight and Kate Selig
title: A Constitutional Convention? Some Democrats Fear It’s Coming.
description: Some Republicans have said that a constitutional convention is overdue. Many Democratic-led states have rescinded their long-ago calls for one, and California will soon consider whether to do the same.
content: As Republicans prepare to take control of Congress and the White House, among the many scenarios keeping Democrats up at night is an event that many Americans consider a historical relic: a constitutional convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Amazon Disregarded Internal Warnings on Injuries, Senate Investigation Claims
description: A staff report by the Senate labor committee, led by Bernie Sanders, uncovered evidence of internal concern about high injury rates at the e-commerce giant.
content: For years, worker advocates and some government officials have argued that Amazon’s strict production quotas lead to high rates of injury for its warehouse employees. And for years, Amazon has rejected the criticism, arguing that it doesn’t use strict quotas, and that its injury rates are falling close to or below the industry average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Max Ends Its Partnership With ‘Sesame Street’
description: The venerable children’s series must find a new home after airing on HBO and then the streaming service Max. Old episodes will be available on Max through 2027.
content: “Sesame Street” is relocating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is It Ever OK to Go Barefoot in Public?
description: A shoeless talk-show appearance leads a reader to contemplate the current rules around going barefoot in public, and our critic weighs in on naked feet in fashion and society.
content: It may seem strange to be discussing the ethics and aesthetics of bare feet in public as Christmas approaches, a time when many of us are contemplating the allure of fuzzy slippers and fleece socks. But very public fashion rule-breaking by celebrities has a way of starting conversations, not to mention trends, and Angelina Jolie did just show up on “The Tonight Show” couch in an elegant long black dress — and no shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Five ‘Bali Nine’ Drug Smugglers Return to Australia After Two Decades
description: The men were the last Australians still imprisoned in Indonesia for trying to smuggle heroin in 2005, in a case that became a diplomatic flashpoint between the countries.
content: The last five members of the so-called Bali Nine, a group of Australians who were convicted of smuggling heroin nearly two decades ago, have been released from prison in Indonesia and are back in Australia, according to the authorities in both countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: The Ordinary Explanations Behind the Mysterious Lights in the Skies
description: As tips roll in, most reported incidents involve piloted planes and hobby drones, not foreign spying or secret programs, officials say.
content: As reports of strange lights in the sky over New Jersey and other parts of the East Coast have grown, government officials have been stating more firmly that, in essence, there is nothing to see here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Griffin
title: With This MoMA Artist, the Painting Does the Talking
description: Marlon Mullen’s show at the Museum of Modern Art, the first by a developmentally disabled artist, speaks volumes.
content: Before Marlon Mullen begins a painting, he likes to tidy his work space. He’ll pre-mix his paints — Golden acrylics in recycled pots — and lay out his brushes and canvas on his table. Often, he’ll empty the studio’s trash cans. Sometimes he’ll even sweep the yard outside, or rearrange objects on the studio shelves according to their relation to colors he plans to use in his painting. As I learned when I visited him in Richmond, Calif., one recent rainy morning, this ritual process can take days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Myanmar’s War Has Forced Doctors and Nurses Into Prostitution
description: Nearly four years into a grinding civil conflict, the economy is in ruins, and people — even professionals with degrees — are desperate.
content: After seven years of medical school in Myanmar, May finally achieved her goal of becoming a doctor. But a month after she graduated and found a job, her dreams started unraveling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Young Republicans Gather, Ready to Make America Vengeful Again
description: At a gala on Wall Street for the New York Young Republican Club, attendees were looking forward to retribution from the next Trump era, and musing on another run in 2028.
content: Late Sunday night, in a banquet hall inside the grand old Merchants’ Exchange building on Wall Street, the Republican operative Stephen K. Bannon was putting on one of his over-the-top, apocalyptic performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Breakout Stars of 2024
description: Across the arts world, these 10 performers broke away from the pack this year by channeling guts and grit into their work.
content: Audacious, original and wielding a clear vision, the stars who rose to the top in 2024 pushed boundaries and made bold, even risky, choices. Here are 10 artists who shook up their scenes and resonated with fans this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Tariq Panja
title: Are Tariffs Inevitable?
description: World leaders and C.E.O.s are struggling to convince President-elect Donald Trump to shift his position on imposing new levies against America’s trade partners and its rivals.
content: Investors appear largely unfazed by President-elect Donald Trump’s tough talk on tariffs, with the S&P 500 up more than 5 percent since Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan
title: A Ride-Hailing Start-Up in Washington Tries to ‘Out-Uber Uber’
description: A company called Empower is trying to take on Uber, Lyft and local regulators as it piles up fines and draws new passengers to its service.
content: On a recent Tuesday morning outside Union Station’s train hall in Washington, a stream of taxicabs, Ubers and Lyfts pulled to the curb to pick up passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: A Hanukkah-Ready Recipe That Does Everything Right
description: Inspired by a Ukrainian cafe and a mother-in-law’s classic, this take on kasha varnishkes is rich with caramelized onions.
content: When my daughter Daniela returned from a work trip to Eastern Europe last summer, she raved about the kasha varnishkes at Kafe Jerusalem, a tiny Ashkenazic Jewish restaurant in Lviv, Ukraine. According to her, it was even better than mine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Gov. Murphy Grants First Pardons, Freeing 3 Women Convicted of Murder
description: The women, who had been abused, were recommended for clemency by a panel that Philip D. Murphy, New Jersey’s governor, set up.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey on Monday commuted the prison sentences of three women who had been abused and were convicted of killing men close to them — as he made the first pardons of his two-term administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rajan Menon
title: Four Scenarios for Ukraine’s Endgame
description: The war is entering what could be its final phase. What happens next?
content: Almost three years after Vladimir Putin ordered Russia’s troops to invade Ukraine, the war is entering what could be its final phase, and a deal to end it seems likelier than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Administration Takes First Step to Retaliate Against China Over Hack
description: The Commerce Department is banning the few remaining operations of China Telecom in the United States, a move that appears unlikely to deter Beijing from conducting sophisticated cyberoperations.
content: The Biden administration has taken its first step to retaliate for China’s broad hack of American telecommunications firms, moving to ban the few remaining operations of China Telecom in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden, Amelia Nierenberg and Isabella Kwai
title: Hundreds Feared Dead After Cyclone Hits French Territory of Mayotte
description: Officials on the archipelago off the eastern coast of Africa said the number of people killed by Tropical Cyclone Chido could be much higher than the 21 now confirmed dead.
content: Emergency workers and families on Monday desperately searched for victims after a storm devastated the French territory of Mayotte, off the eastern coast of Africa. Officials fear that hundreds or even thousands could be dead, far higher than the current confirmed toll of 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Fuller
title: Syrian Rebel Leader Calls for Lifting of Sanctions, as al-Assad Defends Exit
description: Ahmed al-Shara urged nations to remove sanctions from Syria and the terrorism designation from his group so Syria could rebuild. Bashar al-Assad also gave his first account of fleeing to Russia.
content: Ahmed al-Shara, the leader of the rebel coalition that swept into Damascus last week and ousted the Assad regime, urged the United States and other nations to remove sanctions imposed on the country, saying in an interview on Monday that all constraints needed to be lifted so that Syria could rebuild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: An Offhand Remark by Trump Gives a Glimpse Into His Worldview
description: “The first term, everybody was fighting me,” the president-elect said. “In this term, everybody wants to be my friend.”
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump had been holding forth for about an hour when he gave an unsolicited assessment of the difference between his White House transition eight years ago and now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie Give a Surprising Education in Opera
description: “Paris & Nicole: The Encore,” a sequel to “The Simple Life,” is a comedic lark about creating an opera, with enlightening lessons along the way.
content: It was a sight I certainly didn’t expect to see this year, or ever: Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie sitting down with Thomas Adès, one of the greatest living composers, to learn about opera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Bianca Pallaro
title: Adams Is Denied Public Matching Funds, Hampering Re-election Campaign
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board voted to withhold as much as $4.3 million in matching funds from Mayor Eric Adams, as he faces federal corruption charges focused on his fund-raising practices.
content: Mayor Eric Adams was denied public matching funds for his re-election campaign on Monday as he faces federal corruption charges focused on his fund-raising practices, dealing a major setback to his bid for a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Benjamin Weiser
title: Supreme Court Rejects Former Lt. Gov.’s Bid to Dismiss Charges
description: The former lieutenant governor of New York, Brian Benjamin, is accused of funneling state money to a local real estate developer in exchange for campaign contributions.
content: Brian A. Benjamin, the former lieutenant governor of New York, must face trial on federal corruption charges, after the U.S. Supreme Court turned down a request on Monday to dismiss much of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Japan’s SoftBank Makes Big Investment Pledge Ahead of Trump’s Inauguration. Again.
description: The technology company plans to invest $100 billion in U.S. projects, echoing the multibillion-dollar pledge it made after Donald J. Trump’s first election victory in 2016.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s first news conference since the election covered a wide range of topics, but it began with an eye-catching pledge: a $100 billion investment in the United States by SoftBank, a Japanese technology company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Trump’s First Post-Election News Conference
description: The president-elect made inaccurate claims about a small-business survey, the federal budget, autism rates and pesticide use, among other claims.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump, in his first news conference since the election, again displayed his penchant for exaggeration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 16, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 16, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Alaska in Winter: Reveling in a Playground of Ice and Snow
description: Juneau, a popular cruise port in summer, becomes a deal-seeker’s base for skiing, skating, hiking and glacier-gazing in winter.
content: Twelve inches of fresh powder had just fallen at Eaglecrest Ski Area in Juneau, Alaska, when I arrived for my first day of skiing last February. Snow packed the slumping branches of towering pines and frosted the beards of draping moss. From the chairlift, skiers below me appeared from the thighs up, their lower halves plowing fresh tracks. Whoops of delight rang out from sources unseen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,277
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: ‘Unfettered’ Gas Exports Would Harm U.S. Economy, Energy Secretary Warns
description: Jennifer Granholm said a new analysis showed that the continued pace of exports was “neither sustainable nor advisable.”
content: If the United States were to continue exporting liquefied natural gas in the way that has made it the world’s biggest gas supplier, it would drive up costs for American consumers and businesses, pollute struggling communities and increase global greenhouse gas emissions, according to a letter written by Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm that was obtained Monday by The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Gilgo Beach Prosecutor Promises Major Development in Serial Killing Case
description: The defendant, Rex Heuermann, is due in court Tuesday. Investigators have been trying to tie him to other unsolved killings on Long Island.
content: Investigators on Long Island on Tuesday morning will announce a “significant development” in the investigation of Rex Heuermann, the Massapequa Park architectural consultant accused in the Gilgo Beach serial killings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Schmitz
title: Trump Hates the ‘Deep State.’ But He Also Needs It.
description: He should fuse these two impulses into a single governing ideology.
content: Donald Trump won the 2024 election after promising to wage war on elements of the federal work force. “Either the deep state destroys America, or we destroy the deep state,” he said in the first major rally of his campaign. Russell Vought, whom Mr. Trump has tapped to head the Office of Management and Budget, has said he wants bureaucrats to be “increasingly viewed as the villains.” Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, the leaders of Mr. Trump’s new Department of Government Efficiency, promise to enact “mass head-count reductions across the federal bureaucracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Will Stick With You From 2024?
description: What from your own life, around the globe, or in the world of art, culture and sports will you remember about this year?
content: When you look back on 2024, what will you remember?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Ana Ley
title: The Deadly Lure of Subway Surfing
description: For more than a century, people have climbed on top of moving trains in search of a thrill. Now social media has attracted a new generation of daredevils.
content: On a late spring afternoon, two boys celebrating the last day of sixth grade set out through their New York City neighborhood in search of an adventure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Tuesday Briefing: Syria’s New Leader Calls for Lifting Sanctions
description: Plus, the breakout stars of 2024.
content: Ahmed al-Shara, the leader of the rebel coalition that swept to power in Syria last week, urged the U.S. and other nations to lift sanctions against the country, saying in an interview with journalists yesterday that his urgent priority was rebuilding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Trump Says He Would Consider Pardoning Eric Adams
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s comment reflects an unusual relationship that Mr. Adams, the New York mayor, has encouraged as his federal corruption trial nears.
content: The question has hung over New York City politics for months: If Mayor Eric Adams was convicted on federal corruption charges, would Donald J. Trump pardon him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Is the Wrong Answer to the Right Question
description: The president-elect and the president are in transition.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, this is our last conversation of 2024. We’ll be back in January, as will, um, President Trump. Any New Year predictions? Wishes? Desperate hopes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Diamond
title: Is Mikhail Baryshnikov the Last of the Highbrow Superstars?
description: Fifty years since he left the Soviet Union, he insists on using his huge fame to bring attention to difficult, esoteric art.
content: We were on the third or fourth flight of thick marble steps in a prewar Midtown apartment building when Mikhail Baryshnikov turned to ask if I was OK. I was clutching my inhaler, sweat rolling down my forehead. Totally fine, I answered. Was he OK? He was, after all, three decades my senior, with a lifetime of wear from leaps and pirouettes and enough knee surgeries that he forgets the exact number. But his face was dry and his breathing steady: “I think I can manage,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Letby’s Lawyers Seek Appeal After Lead Expert ‘Changed Mind’ on Murders
description: Lawyers for Lucy Letby, a British nurse found guilty of murdering seven babies, said that the prosecution’s expert witness was not reliable after he changed his mind about why three infants died.
content: The defense team for Lucy Letby, a British nurse found guilty of murdering babies in her care, said on Monday that it will ask the Court of Appeal to review all of her convictions, because the lead prosecution expert has changed his mind about how three of the babies died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​Impeachment in South Korea Has Cost Washington a Staunch Ally
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol shifted his country closer to Washington and stood up to Beijing. But that foreign policy could be recalibrated in the future.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol has changed the course of South Korea’s diplomacy like no leader before him. He put his country in lock step with the United States by countering North Korea with sanctions and joint military drills. He won Washington’s plaudits when he overcame a century of historical grievances Koreans held against Japan​ and helped lay the ground for trilateral cooperation to deter China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Joy of Christmas Ornaments (as a Jew)
description: After I met my husband, I realized there was a whole little world inside these ornaments.
content: Growing up, I thought Christmas ornaments were tchotchkes you bought at CVS — shiny, uniform bulbs that came in neat packages of eight. In my secular Jewish family, it never occurred to me that decorating a tree had any value beyond the aesthetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know the London of Charles Dickens?
description: Try this short quiz to see how many landmarks and locations around the city you remember from the great author’s works.
content: Try this short quiz to see how many landmarks and locations around the city you remember from the great author’s works.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Letter
description: Adeel Mangi, who would have been the first Muslim American federal appellate court judge, wrote an angry letter to President Biden describing bigotry he faced in the confirmation process.
content: Adeel Mangi, who would have been the first Muslim American federal appellate court judge, wrote an angry letter to President Biden describing bigotry he faced in the confirmation process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Germany’s Olaf Scholz Loses a Vote of Confidence
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called for the confidence vote after his three-party coalition broke up. Lawmakers voted to dissolve the existing government by a vote of 394 to 207, with 116 abstaining.
content: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called for the confidence vote after his three-party coalition broke up. Lawmakers voted to dissolve the existing government by a vote of 394 to 207, with 116 abstaining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Taylor Fuller
title: House Tour | Dennis Maher
description: The artist’s Victorian home in Buffalo, N.Y., is filled with found objects, including over 100 dollhouses.
content: The artist’s Victorian home in Buffalo, N.Y., is filled with found objects, including over 100 dollhouses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By WKOW via Associated Press and WISN via Associated Press
title: Several Killed in Wisconsin School Shooting, Including Juvenile Suspect
description: The police responded to a shooting at a private Christian school in Madison, Wis., on Monday.
content: The police responded to a shooting at a private Christian school in Madison, Wis., on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nader Ibrahim
title: France Sends Soldiers to Find Survivors Following Cyclone Chido
description: The French territory of Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa was left devastated by Tropical Cyclone Chido. French authorities said it could take days to establish a death toll.
content: The French territory of Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa was left devastated by Tropical Cyclone Chido. French authorities said it could take days to establish a death toll.
source.name: The New York Times
